content: The "Stop the Regulation Invasion Please Act of 2011" or "STRIP Act of 2011" imposes a moratorium on regulatory rulemaking actions by Federal agencies, with emergency exceptions and exclusions. The "STRIP Act of 2011" imposes a moratorium on regulatory rulemaking actions by Federal agencies, with emergency exceptions allowing waivers for actions necessary due to imminent threats to health or safety, enforcement of criminal laws, or other emergencies. The head of the agency must request a waiver from the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs and publish the finding and waiver in the Federal Register. The "STRIP Act of 2011" imposes a moratorium on regulatory rulemaking actions by Federal agencies, with exceptions for emergencies. The head of an agency must publish excluded actions in the Federal Register. Section 2 does not apply to rulemaking actions for discrimination based on age, race, religion, gender, national origin, or disability, except for those using quotas or preferences. SEC. 4. REVIEW OF RULES. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must review and report on rules in effect since October 1, 1991, estimating costs and benefits, recommending whether rules should continue, and identifying minor and major rules. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must review and report on rules in effect since October 1, 1991, estimating costs and benefits, recommending whether rules should continue, and identifying minor and major rules. The total number of minor and major rules that became effective after October 1, 1991, and are in effect as of the date of the enactment of this Act will be included in the report. The Director shall apply a uniform standard for figures and cost summaries in the report. SEC. 5. SUNSET PREVENTION PROCEEDINGS. Designation of Federal Agency Regulatory Review Officer to testify before Congress on preventing rule repeal. Officer can request a hearing on a reviewed rule after 60 days. Officer can request to prevent rule repeal during the hearing by providing a description of the submitted report. Repeal of rules one year after enactment of Act, unless specifically authorized by law. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Federal agency," "major rule," "moratorium period," and "regulatory rulemaking action." The Act defines "regulatory rulemaking action" as any rulemaking published in the Federal Register, excluding cost-benefit analysis or risk assessment. The term "action" does not include agency actions certified by the agency head and the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs to reduce regulatory burdens. The Office of Management and Budget certifies in writing limited to military or foreign affairs, international trade agreements, agency management, personnel, public property, loans, grants, benefits, or contracts. Agency actions certified by the agency head and the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs are limited to routine administrative tasks. The agency's writing is limited to routine administrative functions, agency actions supervised by agencies regulating financial institutions, and actions certified by the agency head for exceptions or exclusions. The agency's role is limited to interpreting, implementing, or administering internal revenue laws of the United States. The term "rule" refers to agency statements designed to implement, interpret, or prescribe law or policy, excluding specific approvals for future rates or financial structures. No private right of action may be brought against any Federal agency for a violation of this Act, but this does not affect any private right of action available under other laws.
